;;周三，丹尼尔风暴在利比亚东北部德尔纳造成的破坏。由于担心疾病流行，市长呼吁人们帮助打捞尸体。
;

;在一场灾难性的洪水造成数千人死亡并席卷许多人之后，利比亚遭受重创的德尔纳市的救援人员呼吁提供更多裹尸袋。出海。

;

;自;风暴丹尼尔于周六晚上袭击了利比亚北部海岸。恐怕有多达 20,000 人死亡。

;

;“我们实际上需要专门负责打捞尸体的团队，”德尔纳市长 Abdulmenam al-Ghaithi 说道。 “我担心这座城市会因为废墟下和水中的大量尸体而感染流行病。”搜索小组负责人卢特菲·米斯拉蒂 (Lutfi al-Misrati) 告诉半岛电视台：“我们需要装尸体的袋子。”

;

;早些时候，管理利比亚东部的政府民航部长希姆·阿布·奇基瓦特 (Hichem Abu Chkiouat) < a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/sep/13/libya-flood-death-toll">;表示“大海不断倾倒数十具尸体”;。海上巡逻队正在沿海寻找被冲上岸的尸体，其中许多尸体被送往托布鲁克进行身份识别。

; ;

;为了避免疾病传播，需要埋葬尸体，因此数百人被集中埋在一个坟墓中。德尔纳居民一直在恳求建立一座新的野战医院，因为该镇现有的两家医院已成为临时太平间。

;

;市长，救援队已从埃及、突尼斯、阿拉伯联合酋长国、土耳其和卡塔尔抵达盖蒂说。土耳其还派遣一艘载有设备的船只前往设立两所野战医院和 148 名医务人员，以帮助救援工作。英国周三宣布了高达 100 万英镑的初步援助计划。

; ;

;多位人工智能专家和其他行业领袖也出席了会议，其中包括比尔盖茨；电影协会首席执行官查尔斯·里夫金（Charles Rivkin）；谷歌前首席执行官埃里克·施密特；人道技术中心联合创始人特里斯坦·哈里斯；

;

;22 名与会者中还包括一些劳工和公民自由团体的代表，其中包括美国劳工联合会-产联 (AFL-CIO) 工会主席伊丽莎白·舒勒 (Elizabeth Shuler)；美国教师联合会主席兰迪·温加滕（Randi Weingarten）；珍妮特·穆尔吉亚 (Janet Murguía)，UnidosUS 主席；以及民用与民用领导力会议主席兼首席执行官玛雅·威利 (Maya Wiley)人权。

;

;不到一年前，ChatGPT 的发布引发了企业界强烈要求应用新的生成式人工智能工具，这些工具可以编写类似人类的文本段落、对计算机代码进行编程并创建新颖的图像，音频和视频。对此类工具的大肆宣传加剧了人们对其潜在社会危害的担忧，并促使人们呼吁提高新产品背后的数据收集和使用方式的透明度。

;

;Meta 与《卫报》分享了他的开场白。马克·扎克伯格表示，该公司正在与学术界、政策制定者和民间社会合作，“最大限度地降低该技术的风险”，同时确保他们不会低估其带来的好处。他特别提到了如何对人工智能内容加水印，以避免虚假信息大规模传播等风险。

;

;在论坛之前，Alphabet 工人工会的代表表示，AFL-CIO 主席舒勒将提出员工问题包括人工智能评估员的问题，他们的任务是培训、测试和评估 Google 搜索和公司人工智能聊天机器人的结果，他们表示自己一直在与低工资和最低福利作斗争。

;

;“仍有许多对话要做，在整个过程中，劳动人民的利益必须成为国会的北极星，”舒勒在一份声明中说。 “工人不是技术变革的受害者——我们才是解决方案。”

; ;

;虽然舒默将这次会议描述为“多元化”，但会议因严重依赖那些有望从生成技术快速进步中受益的人们的意见而受到批评。人工智能技术。 “房间里有一半的人代表将从宽松的人工智能法规中获利的行业，”数字版权组织“争取未来”的活动兼董事总经理凯特琳·西利·乔治 (Caitlin Seeley George) 说。

;

;“这些人实际上受到人工智能影响的人必须在这张桌子上占有一席之地，包括目前已经因人工智能的歧视性使用而受到伤害的弱势群体，”乔治说。 “科技公司已经运行人工智能游戏足够长的时间了，我们知道这会带我们走向何方——带有偏见的算法会歧视黑人和棕色人种、移民、残疾人以及银行业、就业市场、监控和警务领域的其他边缘群体。”

;

;一些参议员对这次非公开会议持批评态度，认为科技高管应该公开作证。共和党参议员乔什·霍利 (Josh Hawley) 表示，他不会参加他所说的“大型科技公司的大型鸡尾酒会”。

; Thu, 14 Sep 2023 08:52:01 +0800 Kim Jong-un invites Putin to North Korea after summit brings ties to ‘a new level’https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/sep/14/kim-jong-un-invites-vladimir-putin-to-north-korea

;;朝鲜领导人金正恩在俄罗斯东方航天发射场会见俄罗斯总统弗拉基米尔·普京
;

;据平壤官方媒体报道，金正恩周三在俄罗斯举行会议期间邀请俄罗斯总统弗拉基米尔·普京访问朝鲜，同时警告金正恩准备为乌克兰战争提供克里姆林宫炮弹和其他弹药。

;

;据朝中社报道，金正恩告诉普京，他们备受关注的会晤将双边关系提升到了新的水平，并表示愿意在未来 100 年建立稳定的、面向未来的关系。

;

;报道接着说，金正日听取了有关俄罗斯航天器的技术细节的简报;在访问航天发射场期间;，但没有提及任何武器供应、武器贸易或武器计划的技术援助。

;

;日本共同社援引消息人士的话称，金正恩计划在与普京会谈后参观一家生产苏霍伊战斗机和其他飞机的工厂。

;
;

;;相关：;;'没有什么可失去的了”：普京在金正恩峰会上扮演破坏者的角色;

;
;

;美国和韩国官员对金正恩可能向俄罗斯提供武器和弹药表示担忧，在乌克兰18个多月的战争中消耗了大量库存。莫斯科和平壤否认了这种意图。

;

;周三，普京多次暗示峰会上讨论了军事合作，但透露的细节很少。俄罗斯国防部长绍伊古出席了会谈。克里姆林宫表示，邻国之间的敏感讨论属于私事。

;

;周三在阿穆尔州偏远地区东方航天发射场举行的会议上，金正恩向普京表示支持俄罗斯对抗西方的“神圣斗争”，而普京则表示支持普京。据报道，俄罗斯就朝鲜陷入困境的卫星计划提供了帮助。

;

;两位领导人的一对一会谈以及与代表团的讨论持续了大约两个小时，随后在金正恩举行了正式晚宴荣誉。克里姆林宫发言人德米特里·佩斯科夫表示，两人还讨论了将朝鲜宇航员送入太空的可能性。

;

;考虑到朝鲜有兴趣推行太空计划，峰会地点的选择意义重大。会谈之前，领导人参观了位于俄罗斯东部森林中、距离中国边境不远的航天发射场的组装和发射设施。

; ;

;周三，美国对俄罗斯与朝鲜之间潜在的新军事合作表示担忧。美国国务院发言人马修·米勒表示，金正恩访问期间宣布的合作“相当令人不安，可能违反多项联合国安理会决议”。

;

;他指出美国对朝鲜卫星的担忧，总统在这些卫星上普京承诺合作，已用于开发平壤的弹道导弹。

;

;米勒表示，美国“将毫不犹豫”在适当的情况下实施制裁。

;

;美国国务卿安东尼布林肯在周三播出的采访中表示，俄罗斯对朝鲜和伊朗的依赖表明了其在乌克兰发动战争时所处的可怕处境。

;

;“这有点像‘星球大战’国家的酒吧场景。因此，我认为这确实说明了俄罗斯的绝望，”布林肯告诉Pod拯救世界播客。

;

;“我们希望确保我们能够在必要时施加成本和后果。”

;

;“我们希望确保我们能够在必要时施加成本和后果。” p>;

;周三，美国批准向韩国出售 F-35，这是具有隐形能力的顶级战斗机。

;

;出售 25 架美国国务院声明称，喷气式飞机“将通过提供可靠的防御能力来阻止该地区的侵略并确保与美军的互操作性，从而提高韩国应对当前和未来威胁的能力”。随着与朝鲜的紧张局势加剧。在金正恩访问俄罗斯时，平壤进行了最新的导弹试验。

;

;美国加强了与日本和韩国这两个美军驻地的盟友的三向合作。 ;上个月在华盛顿附近的戴维营总统度假村;举行的峰会上，美国总统乔·拜登、韩国总统尹锡烈和日本首相岸田文雄承诺加强合作共同应对朝鲜问题和其他挑战。

; Thu, 14 Sep 2023 08:22:01 +0800 Republican congresswoman kicked out of musical for ‘causing disturbance’https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2023/sep/13/lauren-boebert-kicked-out-beetlejuice
;;2023-09-13T21:47:01Z;
;
;;Lauren Boebert
;

;美国国会女议员 Lauren Boebert 被踢出音乐剧 Beetlejuice 的表演in Denver on Sunday, according to security footage.

;

;The theater didn't name Boebert, but a spokesperson said on Wednesday that the video – which showed Boebert and a guest being escorted out of the venue – was of guests who were kicked out after audience members accused them of vaping, singing, using phones and causing a disturbance.

;
;

;;Related: ;;Mitt Romney condemns 'demagogue' Trump as he announces retirement;

;
;

;Her campaign manager confirmed that Boebert was kicked out but denies she was vaping. Boebert and the other guest left.

;

;“I can confirm the stunning and salacious rumors: in her personal time, congresswoman Lauren Boebert is indeed a supporter of the performing arts (gasp!),” said Drew Sexton, Boebert's campaign manager, in a text message, adding that Boebert “pleads guilty to singing along, laughing and enjoying herself”.

;

;Boebert is in her second term in Congress and is running for re-election in Colorado's third congressional district, largely covering the state's western half. The theater disturbance was first reported by the Denver Post.

;

;In her relatively short time in Washington DC, Boebert has built a national profile with a combative style that has grabbed media headlines, most famously by heckling President Joe Biden during his 2022 State of the Union address to Congress.

;

;During the argument in the theater, the two made comments along the lines of “do you know who I am” and “I will be contacting the mayor,” according to the venue's statement.

;

;On the social media platform X, formerly known as Twitter, Boebert said: “Everyone should go see it if you get a chance this week and please let me know how it ends!”

;

;The two guests at first refused to leave the venue, even after an employee threatened to get the police, the theater said in a statement. Once a police officer was on the way, the two left, the theater said.

;

;The security footage provided to the Associated Press does not appear to show Boebert vaping.

; Thu, 14 Sep 2023 07:22:02 +0800 Mexican senate hears testimony on extraterrestrial life: ‘We are not alone’https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/sep/13/mexican-senate-hearing-ufos
;;2023-09-13T22:21:38Z;
;
;;A group of international experts hold a hearing in Mexico's lower house to discuss extraterrestrial sightings in Mexico City, Mexico on Wednesday.
;

;Mexican senators have heard testimony that “we are not alone” in the universe and been presented with the alleged remains of “non-human” mummies, in the country's first official event on extraterrestrial life.

;

;At a senate hearing on Tuesday, lawmakers were shown two shriveled bodies with shrunken heads – alongside video footage of “unexplained anomalous phenomena” – by Jaime Maussan, a former sports journalist-turned UFO-enthusiast.

;

;Maussan said the remains were more than 1,000 years old and belonged to “non-human beings that are not part of our terrestrial evolution”.

;

;“It's the queen of all evidence,” Maussan claimed. “That is, if the DNA is showing us that they are non-human beings and that there is nothing that looks like this in the world, we should take it as such.”

;

;Other studies have suggested the mummies, which were found in Nazca, Peru, in 2017, are fraudulent.

;

;Tuesday's hearing was organised by Sergio Gutiérrez Luna, a lawmaker from the governing Morena party and aspiring governor of the state of Veracruz.

;
;

;;Related: ;;Space oddity: Mexican group claims alien base offers hurricane protection;

;
;

;It included participants from around the world who made calls for transparency and international cooperation. Maussan suggested that Mexico could become the first country in the world to accept the presence of aliens on the planet.

;

;Gutiérrez Luna said that Congress had not taken a position on the theories put forward during the hearing but stressed the important of listening to “all voices, all opinions”.

;

;The event was inspired by the US congressional hearing on the same topic in July, in which the retired Major David Grusch ;alleged that the US was hiding a program to retrieve and reverse engineer UFOs.; The Pentagon has denied his claims.

;

;In media interviews, Grusch has made even more outlandish claims that the US government has in its possession the bodies of “;dead pilots;” and ;a flying saucer; found in Italy by Mussolini almost 100 years ago.

;

;Nonetheless the congressional hearing was a sign of the increased respectability of a field once seen as the reserve of conspiracy theorists.

;

;Well-known politicians, such as Republican senator Marco Rubio, have pushed for more disclosure, and in 2022 Barack Obama told CBS that the government has “footage and records of objects in the skies, that we don't know exactly what they are, we can't explain how they moved, their trajectory”.

; Thu, 14 Sep 2023 06:52:01 +0800 Mitt Romney condemns ‘demagogue’ Trump as he announces retirementhttps://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2023/sep/13/mitt-romney-retirement-trump
;;2023-09-13T19:19:14Z;
;
;;Mitt Romney at the Capitol in February last year.
;

;Senator Mitt Romney of Utah, a former presidential nominee and a rare relative moderate in ;the Republican party of Donald Trump;, has said he will not run for a second term next year, depriving the party of one of its fiercest critics in Congress of the former US president and his political movement.

;
;

;;Related: ;;Rightwing women's group slammed for keynote address by 'misogynist' Trump;

;
;

;“It's pretty clear that the party is inclined to a populist demagogue message,” he said in ;an interview with the Washington Post; in which he announced his retirement.

;

;Romney lost the 2012 presidential election to Barack Obama and entered Congress in 2018. Before that he was governor of Massachusetts between 2003 and 2007.

;

;Amid increased scrutiny of the advanced age of many US politicians, Romney, 76, said it was time for a new generation to “step up [and] shape the world they're going to live in”. He also said he did not think a second term that would end in his 80s could be as effective as his first.

;

;That, Romney ;said;, was in part down to a far-right dominated House Republican party which made it “difficult” for that chamber to “operate”, and in part down to a looming 2024 presidential election between the incumbent, Joe Biden, and his predecessor, Trump.

;

;“Biden is unable to lead on important matters and Trump is unwilling to lead on important matters,” Romney said.

;

;Trump faces 91 criminal charges, including 17 for election subversion and 40 over the retention of classified information, and numerous civil lawsuits – but still leads Republican polling in the 2024 nomination race by huge margins.

;

;Romney ;opposed; Trump's nomination in 2016 and emerged as a rare Republican critic, despite a wobble after Trump won the White House, when Romney appeared ;to seek a cabinet appointment;.

;

;That did not materialise, and Romney eventually became the only Republican senator to vote to convict Trump in both his impeachment trials, for seeking political dirt in Ukraine and for inciting the January 6 attack on Congress. The party did not follow Romney and Trump was twice acquitted.

;

;Speaking ;to the Post;, Romney said: “If there were no cost to doing what's right, there'd be no such thing as courage … I think it's fair to say that the support I get in Utah is because people respect someone who does what they believe is right, even if they disagree with me.”

;

;He also released ;a video message;.

;

;Romney told the Post he would have been open to helping a Republican candidate other than Trump in 2024, but acknowledged Trump's grip on the primary.

; ;

;“I doubt my support will mean anything positive to any of the candidates at the finish line,” Romney said, noting the prominence of other far-right candidates, Ron DeSantis and Vivek Ramaswamy, and saying: “I'm not looking to get involved in that … It's pretty clear that the party is inclined to a populist demagogue message.”

;

;Asked who he thought would win Biden v Trump round two, Romney said: “Today I'd say 50-50. If I had to bet, I'd say it could go either way. So much can happen between now and then.”

;

;He rejected the idea of a third-party candidate, as floated by the centrist group No Labels, perhaps Joe Manchin, the Democratic senator from West Virginia.

;

;“I lobby continuously that it would only elect Trump,” Romney said.

;

;Saying he would not mount “a farewell tour”, Romney said: “I'm not leaving the party, not retiring. You cannot expect me to hit the beach. I'm going to be as productive as I possibly can be.”

;

;Rejecting the idea that Trump had broken his party, he said: “If it can change in the direction of a populist, it can change back in the direction of my wing.”

;

;Romney is the son of a Republican governor, George Romney of Michigan, who ;in 1968; ran for the presidential nomination from the establishment wing of the party.

;

;The most successful Mormon politician in US history, Mitt Romney seized the nomination in 2012. But he was conclusively beaten by Obama, who successfully focused on his opponent's career as a venture capitalist, portraying him as harsh and out of touch.

;

;Still reveling in a rare high point of that campaign – a judgment call about the threat from Russia which Obama did not share – Romney used ;his Post interview; to discourse on foreign policy, rejecting Republican opposition to aid for Ukraine in its war with Russia and praising the Biden administration for its handling of relations with China.

;

;Of threats at home, as demonstrated by the pro-Trump mob which attacked Congress on January 6, Romney said: “I think it's of paramount importance to maintain our commitment to the constitution and the liberal constitutional order … I do believe that our institutions, while under constant barrage, are strong, that our court system is strong and that, fundamentally, the American people stand by the constitution and the constitutional norms.”

;

;Contradicting his earlier contention that the next election would be 50-50, Romney did predict defeat if Trump is the Republican nominee again.

;

;“I know that there are some in Maga world [a reference to Trump's slogan, Make America great again] who would like Republican rule, or authoritarian rule by Donald Trump,” he said.

;

;“But I think they may be forgetting that the majority of people in America would not be voting for Donald J Trump. The majority would probably be voting for the Democrats.”

; Thu, 14 Sep 2023 05:22:01 +0800 Five-month-old baby boy drowns in rescue mission off Lampedusahttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/sep/13/five-month-old-baby-boy-drowns-in-rescue-mission-off-lampedusa
;;2023-09-13T20:23:39Z;
;
;;Refugees queue on the island of Lampedusa
;

;A five-month-old boy has drowned during a rescue operation off the Italian island of Lampedusa after a boat carrying people across the sea from north Africa capsized.

;

;The tragedy occurred as migrant landings on Lampedusa surged, leaving the small island struggling to cope. About 1,850 people landed on Wednesday, bringing the total number of migrants in Lampedusa to more than 6,700, the Ansa news agency said.

;

;The boat the baby was travelling on capsized shortly before it was intercepted by the Italian coastguard. All other passengers were rescued, including the baby's mother, a teenager from Guinea, Ansa said.

;

;The boat had set off from the Tunisian city of Sfax,; a well-known launchpad for sea journeys to Europe;.

;

;Lampedusa, Italy's southernmost point and a first port of call for people crossing from north Africa, has ;long been a flashpoint in Europe's migration crisis;.

;

;Most of those staying there were being hosted at the island's reception centre, which has an official capacity of about 400. Skirmishes between police and hundreds of migrants trying to leave the island erupted on the docks and during the distribution of meals by aid workers but were quickly quelled, the news agency said.

;

;About 123,860 people have arrived in Italy by boat since the start of the year, the latest interior ministry data showed. The figure is almost double what was recorded in the same period of 2022.

;

;On current trends, arrivals are near the peak recorded in 2016, when about 181,500 people arrived in Italy by sea. Between January and August that year, there were about 115,000 landings, compared with 114,526 in the same period in 2023.

;

;Footage from Tuesday showed queues of flimsy boats, packed full of people, waiting to dock at Lampedusa's port.

;

;Giovanni Di Leo, the chief prosecutor for Agrigento, the province that includes Lampedusa, said 112 vessels had arrived on Tuesday, carrying more than 5,000 people, nearly double the previous record of 63 boats registered on one day last month.

;

;“We are all tired and exhausted both physically and psychologically. The situation is becoming unmanageable and unsustainable,” the mayor of Lampedusa, Filippo Mannino, told the Adnkronos news agency on Wednesday.

;

;“What is happening in Lampedusa is that for the first time the Tunisian route has become so busy … and it is difficult to manage compared to the Libyan route,” said Flavio Di Giacomo, a spokesperson for the UN's International Organisation for Migration.

;

;The much shorter trip from Tunisia was prompting more attempts to cross, especially with smaller vessels, making rescue operations more complicated, Di Giacomo said.

;

;Worsening economic and social conditions in Tunisia have contributed to the surge.

;

;Migrants who arrive on Lampedusa are regularly transferred to Sicily to ease overcrowding, but when arrivals surge, this cannot happen quickly enough.

;

;On Wednesday, 1,650 were transferred to the mainland and another 3,750 were set to leave the island on Thursday, Ansa said.

;

;Italy's deputy prime minister Antonio Tajani wrote on social media that the government would “do whatever is necessary to help Lampedusa's residents and the migrants who continue to arrive on the island”.

;

;“Saudi Arabia's use of foreign of sovereign wealth fund resources to attempt to gain influence in the United States should provoke us all.
